author: sky.cactus
content: The problem I have with pretty much every MEV smoothing plan is that it is premised on the assumption that MEV can be reliably/algorithmically identified in a way that isn't gameable.  I don't believe this to be true, which is why I have opposed basically every MEV smoothing suggestion.

author: alexo314
content: you‚Äôre not the only one üòâ some people internally believe you can prove impossibility of ‚Äúperfect‚Äù smoothing if you assume you will never be able to kill sidechannels

author: sky.cactus
content: The only solution I know of that *might* mitigate the problem is if you have a commit-reveal scheme (or commit-VDF-reveal scheme), but that delays everyone's transaction by quite a bit, increases operational cost significantly.  In the VDF case, this introduces a huge amount of complexity and the time between commit and execution would likely need to be very long.  In the case of commit reveal, a user who didn't show back up to reveal at the right time would have to pay for the commit still but their transaction wouldn't show up.

author: sky.cactus
content: Even with commit-reveal schemes, they can *still* be gamed to some extent because an MEV extractor can just commit a bunch of transactions and then only reveal the ones that are profitable (certainly harder to extract value this way, but still possible, and a shared VDF solves this).

author: barnabemonnot
content: this also moves the available MEV to the post-state after things were revealed, e.g., a bunch of trades are committed then revealed, now there is a bunch of arbitrage available. you could send committed transactions trying to extract that arbitrage, not sure what the ordering rule would be in that case, but arb value/MEV can still be extracted either via ~PGA or stat arbitrage

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, good point.  Commit-reveal *only* protects against front-running MEV.  Back running wouldn't be impacted.
